column2: 'Easy debt to get into': Buy now, pay later food purchases worry consumer advocates
column3: Butcher Samantha Walk says buy now, pay later finance is the "way of the future" and her customers love it — but consumer advocates fear food and other consumable purchases on the scheme will further plunge people into debt.

column2: Canada the latest to harness Australian Indigenous fire knowledge to fight wildfire
column3: From Canada to Asia, Africa and Latin America, the world is seeking-out Australian Indigenous fire expertise to help prevent wildfire and curb emissions.

column2: No sheep bottoms were harmed in the making of this jumper
column3: Not all wool producers are happy about the trend towards using non-mulesed wool in Australia's fashion industry. Some say the pressure to phase-out the practice is adding unnecessary pressure in already tough times.

column2: A 24-year-old council worker is taking on fossil fuels and his super fund in a world-first court case
column3: A landmark trial in Australia could potentially change the way superannuation funds invest Australians' almost $3 trillion in retirement savings and pave the way for more climate-change-related litigation.

column2: Chinese birth rate falls to its lowest in 70 years
column3: The country's birth rate in 2019 fell to its lowest since the founding of the People's Republic of China, posing a long-term challenge for the country's government, which faces an ageing population and a slowing economy.

column2: 'Can I have some money please?': Man discovers picture of his own driver's licence being used on Optus website
column3: Australian telecommunications giant Optus has apologised for publishing a man's former driver's licence, including his date of birth and photo, on their website without his permission.

column2: Restored 1940s aircraft offers journey back into the history of luxury air travel
column3: From an aircraft graveyard to being fitted out in its former glory, plane spotters and history buffs can now take a wander through what luxury air travel used to look like.

column2: 'Canberra, come back': Any kind of fool could see Batemans Bay just can't live without tourists
column3: Business owners in the bushfire-affected town of Batemans Bay on the NSW south coast issue a simple plea to their neighbours up the Kings Highway: "Canberra, come back."

column2: Local milk company denied major government contract despite promise to 'Buy Queensland'

column2: ASX hits record for fourth straight day in world-beating 2020 boom

column2: Your best photos from the past week

You can take a look at more photos from across the country on our Instagram, and share your own Instagram photos with us by using #ABCmyphoto on Instagram.

column2: Bar workers reflect on 'lonely existence' under Sydney's lockout laws
column3: They cost Sydney more than $80 billion but hospitality workers say the lockout laws hit more than their hip pockets.

column2: A South Australian financial adviser is accused of swindling $170,000 from clients, court told

column2: Outback governesses turn to social media to encourage and excite new recruits

column2: Calls for shake-up in mining prosecutions as Queensland marks another death

column3: Australian superannuation funds posted their best returns since 2013 last year, and many analysts say investors can thank Donald Trump's economic policies for it.

column2: Don't open up a new bank account, just give it to mum and dad

column2: Facelift to change outback adventure road forever

column2: Mystery surrounding former Nissan boss's escape 'could be the next Netflix show'

column2: Nullarbor road closures from bushfires could hit Perth grocery shelves

column2: 2019 one of the safest years for air travel, despite the Ethiopian Airlines crash

column2: Adelaide nightclub slammed over response to sexual harassment allegations

column2: 'How good's the gold price?': Amid an economic slowdown can the value of gold keep shining?

column2: Huawei says 'survival' is its priority in 2020, after US blacklisting

column2: Trade deal between US and China could be signed next week

column2: How the wallet business is adapting to a cashless economy

column2: From Egg Boy to secret Disney messages, these are the stories that made headlines in 2019

But beneath the headlines were some stories that, for better or worse, you just couldn't scroll past. Can you guess the most clicked on articles of this year?

column2: Education program for older drivers scrapped despite high road toll
column3: A driver education program that helped older South Australian motorists stay safer behind the wheel has been scrapped by the State Government as the state's road toll climbs to its highest in a decade.

column2: Experts say there is 'no chance' interest rates will recover, forcing some to take drastic action
column3: Investing in gold and high-risk shares and selling the family home before they intended to are some of the ways retirees are trying to stay afloat as paltry returns on cash deposits force them to reassess their finances.

column2: Prospective homebuyers warn others to ignore 'for sale' price tag
column3: Properties in Melbourne and Sydney are selling for $100,000 to $200,000 above the advertised price, which buyers say is underquoting, but real estate agents say is due to market gains.

column2: Bulls carry ASX to one of its best years this century
column3: Against all manner of difficulties, including slowing domestic and global economies, the ASX has powered back over some rough patches and scandal to put on 21 per cent. Stephen Letts looks at how it unfolded.

column2: If you see a sleepy lizard road sign, you have a seven-year-old reptile lover to thank
column3: A sleepy lizard road sign, inspired by a seven-year-old animal lover, pops up in a South Australian national park and is catching on elsewhere in the state.

column2: Cruise industry issues warning over Aboriginal access fees for coastal sites
column3: A West Australian tourism body warns that an increasing number of access fees charged by traditional owners could make cruises along the coast unaffordable.

column2: 'We love this property': Bushfire destruction fuels rethink of how to build safer houses
column3: Standing in a pile of rubble, Faith Gordon is still coming to terms with seeing her house destroyed by fire. She vows to rebuild in the bush, with her next house hopefully built to survive a bushfire if it happens again.

column2: 'Call me a farmer': Why young women are needed for the future of regional communities
column3: Jemma Brown wants people to call her what they call her brother — a farmer. But despite an increasing number of women entering the industry, she's still challenged by gender stereotypes.

column2: In far-north SA, an entire town is being evicted by the government
column3: Residents in South Australia's far north say they are being forced out of their town before New Year's Day, despite the state experiencing its second heatwave in the past two weeks.

column2: Australian coffee is the new gold standard — and not just for 'chin-stroking inner-urban Instagrammers'
column3: From New York to Paris and Berlin, Australian-style coffee is taking hold. But how did a colonial outpost with tea-drinking British roots come to produce the best coffee in the world?

column2: Aussie dollar lifts to five-month high as Nasdaq jumps above 9,000 points
column3: The Australian share market posts modest gains after a two-day Christmas break, boosted by gold miners, while Wall Street pushes new record highs again.

column2: It's almost 2020 and we're still buying diaries and stationery. Here's why
column3: If you thought the smartphone and Facebook marked the end of snail mail and handwritten diaries, you were wrong.

column2: How low-income women are saving slightly more for their super after having babies
column3: Australian women, working part-time or in low income earning roles, may be eligible for an extra $500 at tax time that goes towards saving for retirement.

column2: Is it financially worth it to grow your own food?
column3: For me, nothing beats the taste of a fresh-picked tomato. In fact, many of the benefits of home gardening are hard to put a value on. But what if we tried to? Are home-grown veggies always the most cost-effective option?

column2: 'Call the cops!': Man clings to bull bar of moving ute for 3km
column3: A row between two men involved in a minor collision in Western Sydney descends into a bizarre road-rage incident in which one man drives off with the other clinging to the bull bar of his vehicle.

column2: 'The results are amazing': How new tool helps calm down cranky shoppers
column3: As shoppers flock to the Boxing Day sales, retail assistants have a new tool for dealing with angry or abusive customers, thanks to a training course on how to calm angry customers.

column2: Boxing Day sales draw crowds for predicted day of record-breaking spending
column3: Thousands of Boxing Day bargain hunters rush into stores across the country for what's expected to be a record-breaking day of spending, following flagging sales in the lead-up to Christmas.

column2: With thousands exposed to unsafe quantities of silica, this expert is blaming enforcement
column3: The number of known silicosis cases in Australia is rapidly climbing, with the spike being driven by a trend towards engineered stone benchtops. One expert says the silica in them is significantly more toxic than asbestos.

column2: In the age of Netflix, this is why Boxing Day cinema still matters
column3: If you thought Netflix is killing going to the movies, cinema operators and the film studios that supply them want you to think again — and Boxing Day shows why you should.

column2: Vladimir Putin tells Russians their defence technology has leapt ahead of US for first time
column3: President Vladimir Putin claims Russia is the only country in the world that can deploy hypersonic weapons, which places it ahead of its arch-foe, the United States, for the first time in modern history.

column2: Uber co-founder Travis Kalanick leaves board and cashes out $3b in shares
column3: Travis Kalanick, the pugnacious co-founder of Uber, severs his last ties with the ride-services company, resigning from the board and selling all his shares as he turns his focus to a new venture creating "ghost kitchens" for food delivery services.

column2: How a penniless Italian migrant became a supermarket mogul
column3: Tony Bernardi came to Australia with just a few pounds in his pocket and big dreams, but today he heads a regional grocery empire.

column2: China denies forced labour accusations after prisoner's plea found in Christmas card
column3: China dismisses accusations about forced labour inside a Shanghai prison, a day after media reports about note from a purported inmate being found in a Christmas card in England.

column2: Boxing Day shoppers expected to spend record amount in 2019
column3: One of Australia's leading retail groups is predicting Boxing Day sales will hit a record this year, following weaker-than-expected Christmas buying.

column2: ASX flat as US-China trade optimism lifts Wall Street to record highs
column3: Australian shares were practically flat on Christmas Eve, while anticipation for a US-China "phase one" trade deal pushes Wall Street to fresh records.

column2: Looking for Bingo: Parents' pre-Christmas quest for Bluey's little sister
column3: Fans of the hit Australian TV series are using social media to track down a toy from the show in time for Christmas, but it's not the main character they're after, and the series' creators admit they were "caught by surprise".

column2: Boeing sacks CEO to restore confidence after 737 MAX crashes
column3: Boeing fires Dennis Muilenburg as chief executive following intense scrutiny set off by two fatal crashes of its 737 MAX jetliner.

column2: Thinking of buying a holiday home? Analysts say consider these towns
column3: After years in the doldrums, many of Australia's regional property markets are picking up as city slickers search for a sea or tree change in retirement, or even early in life.

column2: As farmers struggle with the drought, regional businesses are struggling too
column3: It's been three years since NSW had a decent harvest and the Lees family are scraping by week-to-week as work for their trucking business becomes harder to find.

column2: Multinationals caught up in the tax crackdown are disputing their bills, the ATO says
column3: Australian companies across mining, oil and gas, e-commerce and the pharmaceutical industry are disputing billions of dollars in tax bills raised under tougher laws aimed at fighting multinational profit shifting, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) says.

column2: Retailers blame fires for worst Christmas shopping season since global financial crisis
column3: The Australian Retailers Associations says it expects to see the weakest Christmas spending in 11 years, with the bushfire crisis coming on top of already weak consumer spending.

column2: Ampol to return to Australia after two decades as Caltex forced to rebrand
column3: Caltex Australia plans to rebrand its service station network and corporate name to Ampol within the next three years after US oil giant Chevron terminates permission for it to use the 'Caltex' name.

column2: Cotton On launches investigation into supplier linked to Tesco 'prison labour' Christmas card
column3: After a plea for help from a purported "foreign prisoner" in China is discovered inside a Christmas card sold at a Tesco in the UK, Australia's Cotton On Group launches an investigation into the same supplier.

column2: Pharma giant hit by fine for misleading local doctors over opioid drug
column3: Mundipharma is slapped with a $302,400 fine by the Therapeutic Goods Administration for a series of advertisements deemed "misleading, imbalanced and otherwise inaccurate".

column2: French railway company backtracks on plan to cancel children's train service
column3: After an outcry, striking train drivers from rail company SNCF agree to operate a popular service that allows children aged between four and 14 to travel unaccompanied by a parent or carer over Christmas.

column2: 'It's crazy': Boutique alcohol producers pleading for tax relief
column3: Independent distillers and winemakers call for a change to alcohol tax rules, saying their products can be shipped to the other side of the world and sell for less than they do in Australia.

column2: Prawn prices on the rise ahead of Christmas as drought hits supply
column3: Prawn lovers in New South Wales are facing higher-than-normal prices this Christmas as the drought takes its toll on the commercial fishing industry.

column2: 'People are going to lose out big time if we don't have tax reform. Really big time'
column3: Ten years ago, Ken Henry handed his boss Wayne Swan Australia's first major tax review in more than 30 years. A decade on, it sits gathering dust, and its lead author says that's costing Australia "big time".

column2: Hong Kong's colour-coded revolution: 'Yellow' cafes get customers, 'blue' ones get smashed
column3: A long line outside a Hong Kong restaurant doesn't necessarily mean it has the best dumplings. It could just mean the business is out and proud about its sympathy for pro-democracy protests.

column2: Is 2020 the year Australia's record-breaking economic run ends in recession?
column3: This year was one many would like to forget when it comes to Australia's economy and, for 2020, economists surveyed by the ABC see lower interest rates, a slight pick up in growth but also risks to the downside.

column2: Tesco suspends Chinese supplier after secret message found in Christmas card
column3: A six-year-old London girl finds a secret message in a Christmas card, purporting to be from a foreigner imprisoned in Shanghai who is being forced to work against their will.

column2: Farmers warn food prices will rise after months without rain
column3: Queensland farmers are warning consumers they will need to pay more for fresh fruit and vegetables, as well as meat, due to the ongoing drought.

column2: In the Australian tropics, free-falling property prices are an opportunity for this battler family
column3: As median unit prices in Alice Springs surpass those in Darwin, struggling Top End residents like Melissa Coles are seeing a silver lining in the depressed real estate market.

column2: Payday lenders targeting vulnerable communities prompts call to expand no interest loan network
column3: Tina Edwards was desperate for a fast loan to help pay for surgery for her three-year-old son, but her options were limited. She found she could get a no-interest loan through a local community centre and avoid a loan from a high-interest payday lender.

column2: 'We firmly reject this': Germany rebukes US over sanctions on critical gas pipeline
column3: Germany has delivered a rebuke to the US after President Donald Trump signed a bill barring firms from working on a pipeline that delivers Russian gas to Europe.

column2: I spent the day with Santa in a shopping centre. This is what kids asked him for
column3: What do you imagine the modern child asks Santa for when they meet him at a suburban shopping centre? The answers might surprise you.

column2: This town should be full of tourists — instead it's full of smoke
column3: Batemans Bay would usually be gearing up for one of its busiest weekends of the year, but bushfires have cut two major highways, disconnecting it from Canberra and Sydney.

column2: 'Life is tough enough': Northern Australians ditch insurance as premiums soar
column3: Many people in disaster-prone areas of northern Australia are choosing to opt out of insurance because they can't afford it, according to the ACCC.

column2: Why Cate's had 40 housemates for eight years
column3: When most people enter the housing market, they want to stop sharing with people besides their partners and children, but for Cate, co-habiting provided the perfect path to having a home.

column2: Popbitch, the online newsletter that scooped everyone on Weinstein, Spacey
column3: It began as a quiet protest against an increasingly PR-controlled media industry, but one email newsletter has become a scandal soothsayer.

column2: Boris Johnson wins Commons vote on Brexit deal in time for Christmas
column3: Boris Johnson has won approval for his Brexit deal in the House of Commons, the first step towards fulfilling his election pledge to deliver Britain's departure from the European Union by January 31.

column2: French telecom company Orange found guilty over workers' suicides
column3: French phone and internet provider Orange has been found guilty of "moral harassment" that resulted in a string of employee suicides during the late 2000s, a Paris court has ruled.

column2: World Bank warns there could be another GFC in store
column3: The World Bank warns the largest and fastest rise in global debt in half a century could lead to another financial crisis amid the slowing world economy.

column2: Volkswagen given biggest ever fine for contravening consumer law
column3: The motor vehicle manufacturer is hit with a double whammy in one day — fined $125 million for misleading consumers about its diesel emissions and hit with allegations that it broke responsible lending laws.

column2: Do fans help cool you down in a heatwave, or just make it hotter?
column3: An expert explains whether fans really do bring some relief during sweltering heatwave conditions or whether they are just pushing around hot air.

column2: 'Like mobile phone number portability for your banking': delay hits seismic shift in customer power
column3: Open banking, one of the most seismic changes to hit the financial services industry, giving customers more power — and better enabling them to switch providers — has been delayed.

column2: Mine worker buried alive for more than two hours, court hears
column3: A WA mine is fighting charges it failed to provide a safe environment following a near-fatal accident. The incident saw an excavator operator buried alive as the floor of an open pit collapsed into a massive void.

column2: US shares rise on hopes that China trade deal won't be lost in translation
column3: US stocks again hit record highs, as the nation's Treasury secretary says a trade deal with China is complete and is now just going through translation.

column2: 'Exponential growth' in business climate action as more investors abandon coal
column3: Investors are voting with their dollars, as one of the world's biggest investment banks joins other financial institutions in ruling out finance for coal-fired power generation.

column2: UN asked to pressure Siemens to drop Adani contract
column3: Australian Greens leader Richard Di Natale calls on the United Nations to stop itself being used for "greenwashing" by multinational Siemens, which has agreed to work on Adani's coal mine.

column2: Queen Elizabeth opens UK Parliament with lengthy list of Boris Johnson's Brexit promises
column3: Queen Elizabeth II opens a new session of Britain's Parliament, with a speech laying out Prime Minister Boris Johnson's plans to use his commanding majority to take Britain out of the European Union on January 31 and shake up the country's public services.

column2: It was a 'complicated' and 'difficult' project, but the new $396m WA Museum building is finally finished
column3: The WA Government says it will scrap the $15 entry fee for the new state-of-the-art WA Museum for 18 months as the building reaches a key construction milestone ahead of its opening next November.

column2: Pineapple production slashed as dry weather hits farmers
column3: Pineapple prices have soared and packing sheds are struggling to keep up with Christmas supply as dry weather impacts the summer crop.

column2: Equinor defends Great Australian Bight drilling plans as oil spill fears continue
column3: A Norwegian oil company granted environmental approval to drill in some of Australia's roughest seas tries to ease fears about any oil leaks as it continues to clean up a spill about 17,000 kilometres away in the Bahamas.

column2: Westpac slugged $9 million after employee gives superannuation advice that benefits him
column3: Westpac is fined $9 million after corporate watchdog ASIC took it to court accusing a former bank employee of not acting in his clients' best interests.

column2: Monsanto Roundup class action underway in Federal Court
column3: The first proceedings are underway in a class action against Monsanto, over claims commonly used herbicide Roundup causes cancer.

column2: Unemployment rate falls ahead of Christmas as 40,000 jobs added
column3: The Treasurer and Reserve Bank board will rest easier over the Christmas holidays, after the latest official data show a fall in both unemployment and underemployment.

column2: This repeatedly debunked climate claim won Fact Check's Golden Zombie for 2019
column3: In a year of crippling drought, bushfires, and a bitterly fought federal election campaign, one repeatedly debunked claim stood out among the rest. RMIT ABC Fact Check wraps up the year that was in fact checking.

column2: Google's $500m Aussie tax bill hardly dents Alphabet shares; Wall St flat
column3: Google agrees to pay the Australian Government $481.5 million to settle a tax dispute with the ATO, but US investors hardly notice the impost during a quiet session on Wall Street.

column2: More than 20 sculptures submerged off north Queensland coast for underwater dive attraction
column3: Year 6 student Takoda Johnson is pretty chuffed to be the inspiration for a sculpture at the Townsville Strand, which is part of the Southern Hemisphere's first Museum of Underwater Art.

column2: Maps reveal 'illegal' plans to chop down untouched Australian trees
column3: Last year the ABC caught state-owned loggers illegally chopping down trees on public land, but instead of being punished they were compensated. Now it seems they plan to do it again.

column2: 'I don't want to leave': The residents in the path of North East Link construction
column3: The Borlase Reserve in Melbourne's north is part of Mariella Di Fabio's perfect retirement dream. But the reserve is to become a staging ground for the North East Link, leaving her and other residents angry about what might happen to their "wonderful little community".

column2: Opal Tower builder speaks out as residents return home in time for Christmas
column3: It was last Christmas Eve that the "nightmare" began for Opal Tower residents. The building was evacuated and they were forced them into temporary accommodation. This Christmas they are back home, but they say their "backs are being scraped" as their battle for compensation looms.

column2: Journalist Shiori Ito, the face of Japan's #MeToo movement, wins damages in rape case
column3: A Tokyo court orders a prominent television journalist to pay Shiori Ito 3.3 million yen in damages, a verdict welcomed by women's rights advocates in a country where sexual assault victims often stay silent.

column2: 'Big win for human rights': Journalist who was barred from Vanuatu allowed to return
column3: A Supreme Court allows former Daily Post media director and journalist Dan McGarry to return to his family in Vanuatu after he was banned for China influence stories.

column2: Equinor wins environmental approval to explore for oil in Great Australian Bight
column3: A controversial plan to explore for oil in the Great Australian Bight next year is one step closer, with Norwegian oil company Equinor winning environmental approval for a well off the South Australian coast.

column2: Miners without work a week before Christmas as Cook Colliery shut down by receivers
column3: As central Queensland firm Bounty Mining enters voluntary administration, the miners union says hundreds of workers will be affected by the resulting shutdown of Cook Colliery in the Bowen Basin.

column2: Defying the drought: First chickpeas of season ready to go
column3: Despite the significant effects of drought on Australia's chickpea production, Queensland's first harvest of the season has been loaded onto a ship, ready for export.

column2: New Zealand freezes imports from Queensland after exotic disease found in watermelons
column3: Queensland melon exports to New Zealand have been put on ice after the detection of a cucurbit virus in a shipment of melons.

column2: Wine regions cut off from Uber service amid State Government Christmas crackdown
column3: Uber and other ride-sharing services have stopped accepting fares in the Barossa Valley and the Adelaide Hills in response to "compliance activity" from the South Australian Government.

column2: $1b 'wiped off farm incomes from 20 years of climate change'
column3: Farmers' pockets have been hit hard by a warmer, drier climate over the past two decades, with broadacre profits slashed by more than 20 per cent.

column2: 'They'll send us bankrupt': NAB's bosses face shareholder anger after latest ASIC lawsuit
column3: NAB tells investors it is aiming for a "constructive" relationship with regulators, as ASIC takes the bank to court for allegedly breaching corporate laws more than 12,000 times in relation to the fees-for-no-service scandal.

column2: US shares edge up to fresh records on good economic news
column3: The US stock market trades around record levels again as investor confidence is bolstered by good economic data.

column2: 'They're using government infrastructure for free': Questions over NT's ship lift arrangement
column3: The billion-dollar, Darwin-based Paspaley Pearling Company will collect any revenue generated from users of the Government-owned $400 million ship lift. Concerns are now being flagged about how the project will benefit Territory taxpayers.

column2: North Australian cotton industry continues to expand
column3: As the drought drags Australian cotton production to a decade low, northern producers are ramping up production.

column2: Can you smell that? Durian parties taking off in Australia
column3: Durian parties have starting popping up in parts of Melbourne and Sydney. Can you smell it?

column2: Country newspapers under the Australian Community Media banner to lose editors
column3: The four editors of country newspapers owned by Australian Community Media in South Australia will have their roles cut as part of a re-structure.

column2: Emma's timeline was 12 weeks, her budget was $100k. Here's how she built a home for her family
column3: When a relationship breakdown left Emma unable to pay her mortgage, instead of selling she decided to rent her house out and build a new home in her backyard — it only cost her $100,000.

column2: The spies and Liberal Party doyens embroiled in a bitter corporate takeover battle
column3: Liberal Party doyens and the nation's top spies have been caught up in a brutal takeover battle between Australian engineering giant Worley and its Middle Eastern suitor, Dar.

column2: Fears Melbourne's Docklands will 'die a quiet death' as pier debacle claims hundreds of jobs
column3: Central Pier at Docklands is normally a hive of activity over the pre-Christmas period but more than 100 staff at local businesses have lost their jobs, as the entertainment precinct remains closed until at least January over safety concerns.

column2: Going deep underground to keep this town alive
column3: The ABC has been given rare access underground in one of Cobar's four mines, as it looks below the surface to secure its future with the world's most precious resource — water.

column2: Mine worker killed on remote WA road, three others injured
column3: Police are investigating a crash on a remote Western Australian road which killed a BHP worker and injured three Rio Tinto employees.

column2: Jozef and Anet dropped their daughter off at child care. It was the last time they saw her alive
column3: The Maragols dropped off their smiling little girl at her childcare centre one morning in August last year. When they next saw her that afternoon, she was dead. They are still battling to find out exactly what happened.

column2: Major link between Armadale and Mandurah rail lines delayed until 2023 after $200m cost blowout
column3: The budget for one of the WA Government's signature Metronet rail projects blows out by more than $200 million, with the completion date also pushed out by two years.

column2: Truckies release confronting footage in wake of fatal crash
column3: Trucking authorities issue an urgent plea to motorists to take extra care on the roads this festive season, just hours after a fatal head-on collision between a motorbike and a truck in Adelaide's north.

column2: Battle-ready brigade in the Northern Territory becomes Australia's first line of defence
column3: Around 3,500 soldiers from the 1st Brigade, based predominantly at Darwin's Robertson Barracks, are certified as the Australian Army's 'ready' group after months of intense preparation.

column2: Mariah fans finally boost Christmas classic to Billboard #1, 25 years after release
column3: Arguably one of the best Christmas songs of the generation, Mariah Carey's holiday classic has just smashed records a quarter of a century after it was released.

column2: 'The timing's awful': Building supplier folds just before Christmas, leaving hundreds without jobs
column3: A Melbourne-based business group which employs workers across Sydney, Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide goes into administration, leaving 400 people without jobs a week out from Christmas.

column2: Why is it so hard to recruit and retain hairdressing staff? It's complicated
column3: Hairdressers are worried they'll become "the new blacksmiths" with the art of the trade lost to low wages and tough conditions in an unregulated industry.

column2: 78,000 more cars identified in new Takata airbag warning
column3: The ACCC issues a new warning for thousands of cars with "potentially deadly airbags" ahead of the peak Christmas travel season, warning that they could cause serious injury.

column2: Fines issued after petrol bowser audit reveals under-pouring around the country
column3: One in 20 petrol bowsers audited nationally have been found to be under-pouring petrol, the National Measurement Institute says, with thousands of motorists potentially getting less fuel than they paid for.

column2: 'The last thing we need': Mega-fire could hit power station, coal mine
column3: A statewide total fire ban is issued for the next four days with temperatures forecast to soar, while the Rural Fire Service works to fight a large blaze threatening a power station and coal mines near Lithgow, in the Blue Mountains.

column2: APRA bears down on Westpac management over money laundering scandal
column3: Westpac's directors and senior managers face potential bans from the banking industry, as the sector's regulator launches an investigation into their handling of alleged money laundering breaches.

column2: Trade deals will boost US growth 0.5pc says Kudlow, shares climb
column3: Shares are rising after a top White House official said the first phase of a trade deal between the US and China has been completed.

column2: Jan Brown walked away from a deadly plane crash. Here's why she says flights are dangerous for families
column3: Thirty years ago, studies revealed unrestrained children are at high risk during turbulence and doomed during crashes, but lap infants are still permitted to fly globally.

column2: Going west: The other side of Sydney's 'latte line'
column3: The "latte line" is an imaginary border which starts at Sydney Airport and travels diagonally north-west towards Parramatta. For those looking at which side of the line to live on, it is a case of houses versus jobs.

column2: Woolworths has begun paying back millions in unpaid wages, shareholders told
column3: Woolworths says it has started paying back some of the estimated $200 million to $300 million it owes its workers, as its CEO says the scandal does not amount to "wage theft".

column2: 'Dirty great big freeway' nominated for heritage protection over 'cultural' value to Victoria
column3: Traffic snarls on the Eastern Freeway frequently draw the ire of motorists, but the road also is historically and culturally significant and should be protected, according to the Heritage Victoria.

column2: Jetstar cuts back January flights as wage dispute intensifies
column3: Jetstar will drop 10pc of its domestic flights in January, saying union demands for a 15pc pay rise are unsustainable. But the unions have accused Jetstar of "exaggerating" and "misreporting".

column2: Government blames drought, bushfires and weak global economy for surplus slump
column3: The Federal Government blames "the effects of drought and bushfires" and "weak momentum in the global economy" for a revision that has knocked about $2 billion off the forecast surplus this financial year.

column2: Thousands of unfair VET FEE-HELP debts could be wiped — if students knew how
column3: When Bianca Hackett's training college collapsed she was left with no diploma and thousands of dollars in debt. Finally she has some redress.

column2: As the boom looms, council to spend millions to keep housing affordable
column3: The City of Karratha wants to invest up to $35 million of ratepayer funds to boost local housing stock for an expected industrial boom next year.

column2: Customers demand police exhume body of cryptocurrency boss who died without giving anyone his password
column3: Lawyers representing the customers who lost money in insolvent cryptocurrency exchange QuadrigaCX demand founder Gerald Cotten's body be exhumed to address what they say are "questionable" circumstances surrounding his death and to confirm he is dead.

column2: Qantas passengers use emergency slides to evacuate plane at Sydney Airport
column3: Qantas passengers slide down the emergency exits of the plane after a "hydraulic issue" forces a Sydney to Perth flight to return to Sydney Airport.

column2: Ghost town buildings looking for a saviour
column3: Stone buildings are all that is left of these railway towns now that all but a few people have left. But should they be preserved or left to ruin?

column2: Meet the team of highly trained seafarers protecting Fremantle Port
column3: They scale ships the size of buildings to keep $30 billion in goods flowing through one of Australia's biggest shipping hubs each year. This photo essay reveals the men and women of Fremantle Port.

column2: Sydney and Melbourne's links to Hong Kong's troubled metro train system
column3: Hong Kong's rail network is considered a world-leader, and it has exported its franchises to Melbourne and Sydney. But could the Asian city's ongoing unrest derail our services?

column2: E-scooters — fast, cheap, more convenient than bike riding and illegal in most Australian states
column3: Calls are mounting for new national laws to regulate e-scooters as sales increase, people flout the laws, and police turn a blind eye.

column2: Myer cash registers crash during peak Christmas shopping
column3: Just 11 days out from Christmas, department store chain Myer suffers nationwide technical issues causing registers to restart in stores.

column2: Sydney Light Rail 'fail' as trams come to a halt just hours after official opening
column3: Hours after the $2.96-billion Sydney Light Rail service officially opened, a technical fault halts services at Circular Quay.

column2: Smith heroics not enough as India levels series
column3: India beats Australia by 36 runs in Rajkot, despite Steve Smith's exceptional 98 to set up a deciding clash on Sunday.

column2: 'Bloody nuts': Kagiso Rabada's Test suspension after wicket celebration prompts mixed response
column3: An accumulation of offences by Kagiso Rabada means South Africa will be without its best bowler for the next Test against England.

column2: Sizzling spectators, laptops melting in the heat — returning Test cricket to the WACA isn't the answer
column3: People view the WACA Ground with a nostalgic fondness, but make no mistake, the ageing venue isn't the solution if Perth Stadium misses out on blockbuster summer Test matches, writes Clint Thomas.

column2: Just one squad surprise as dominant Aussies plot T20 World Cup glory
column3: Australia names a settled squad as it prepares to defend its women's T20 World Cup title on home soil next month, with 18-year-old all-rounder Annabel Sutherland the only shock call-up to the team.

column2: Aussie paceman Pat Cummins named ICC Test cricketer of the year
column3: Australia's big year in cricket is recognised, with fast bowler Pat Cummins named ICC Test player of the year, as five Australians make the Test XI for 2019.

column2: David Warner and Aaron Finch both scored centuries
column3: Australia won by ten wickets in their biggest ODI win in India, reaching the hosts' total of 255 with 12 overs to spare.

column2: Australia thrashes India in first ODI as Warner, Finch both hit tons
column3: Australia thrashes India in the first ODI by ten wickets thanks to twin centuries from David Warner and Aaron Finch, wrapping up victory with 74 balls to spare.

column2: Cricket fan banned for two years for racially abusing Jofra Archer
column3: A New Zealand cricket fan is banned for two years after admitting to racially abusing Jofra Archer in the first Test between England and New Zealand in November.

column2: 'We are ready and up for the challenge': Virat Kohli open to pink-ball Aussie Test
column3: The last time India toured Australia, a day-night Test was off the agenda — but now skipper Virat Kohli leaves the door open for a pink-ball Test next summer.

column2: Marcus Stoinis breaks record for highest-ever Big Bash score in Melbourne's win over the Sixers
column3: Stoinis's unbeaten 147 from 79 balls was 25 runs better than the previous record set by D'arcy Short in January 2018.

column2: Marcus Stoinis breaks record for highest-ever Big Bash score in Melbourne's win over the Sixers
column3: Stoinis's unbeaten 147 from 79 balls was 25 runs better than the previous record set by D'arcy Short in January 2018.

column2: Stoinis 'carried' burden of homophobic slur during record Big Bash innings
column3: Marcus Stoinis used the reaction to his homophobic slur to hit an epic BBL record score for the Melbourne Stars against the Sydney Sixers at the SCG.

column2: Ponting and Warne launch charity cricket match for bushfire victims
column3: Australian cricket greats Ricky Ponting and Shane Warne will take to the field on February 8 in a charity game to raise funds for the bushfire appeal.

column2: Shane Warne's baggy green goes for $1 million for bushfire relief
column3: The bidding stops on Shane Warne's baggy green —with the Commonwealth Bank stumping up just over $1 million to own a piece of cricket history and help boost bushfire relief.

column2: Being born without eyes won't stop Sean trying to break the record as Australia's youngest cricketer
column3: Teenager Sean Kendrick is on the cusp of being the youngest blind cricketer to represent Australia if he succeeds in getting selected after playing for Queensland at the National Cricket Inclusion Championships.

column2: Rashid Khan and Haris Rauf both took hat-tricks within hours of each other
column3: Rauf bowled a hat-trick in the final over to restrict the Sydney Thunder to a modest 5-145. Earlier, Khan got a hat-trick against the Sydney Sixers but it wasn't enough for his team though, they lost by two wickets.

column2: BBL becomes Big Bowl League with two hat-tricks in a day
column3: Who says the Big Bash is all about the batsmen? Haris Rauf and Rashid Khan take hat-tricks, hours apart, for the Melbourne Stars and Adelaide Strikers.

column2: Sydney Thunder spinner banned for illegal bowling action
column3: Chris Green receives a 90-day ban after being found to have an illegal bowling action in a Big Bash match between the Sydney Thunder and the Melbourne Stars.

column2: Warne auctions beloved baggy green for bushfire relief
column3: Shane Warne puts one of the most valuable mementos from his decorated cricket career up for auction, joining the fundraising drive for bushfire victims.

column2: Australia caps its dominant summer of cricket with an enjoyable flourish
column3: The Australian team completed a dominant summer in fine form with victory at the SCG — but it has felt more like a preview of things to come, rather than the main event, writes Dan Colasimone.

column2: Aussies thrash Black Caps in SCG Test to complete series whitewash
column3: Australia makes it a perfect summer by defeating New Zealand by 279 runs in the third Test at the SCG, as the hosts enjoy a 3-0 series clean sweep against their trans-Tasman rivals.

column2: Black Caps' SCG resistance can't mask one-sided summer
column3: As New Zealand prepares to go gentle into the good night, it's hard not to wish for a more competitive summer, writes Dan Colasimone.

column2: Stars' Marcus Stoinis fined for homophobic slur against Renegades' Kane Richardson
column3: The Melbourne Stars all-rounder is fined but not suspended for directing a homophobic slur towards his Melbourne Renegades opponent during their Big Bash clash at the MCG.

column2: Dominant Australia leads by 243 runs after Lyon's five-wicket haul
column3: Australia bowls New Zealand out off the back of Nathan Lyon's maiden Test SCG five-for on "pink day" in Sydney, before building a lead of 243 by the close.

column2: Marnus Labuschagne's concentration once nearly cruelled his career
column3: These days Marnus Labuschagne is a paragon of patience at the batting crease but it wasn't always the case. If things had been different, an aloof Abu Dhabi moment could have cost him his Test career, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Marnus Labuschagne's double century leaves Aussies on top in SCG Test
column3: Marnus Labuschagne's 215 leads Australia to a total of 454 against New Zealand, as the hosts chase a series clean sweep in the third Test at the SCG.

column2: 'When I play I forget my past life': Meet the champion asylum-seeker cricketers
column3: This champion suburban Sydney cricket team is composed of Tamil asylum seekers and their success is proving a welcome distraction from their lives in limbo.

column2: At the SCG, this was the day that didn't matter
column3: The New Year's Test at the SCG usually has some meaning to it, but with the series dead in the water and fires engulfing Australia's south-east, few days of Test cricket have mattered less, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Labuschagne century helps Aussies dominate Kiwis on day one
column3: Australia punishes a much-changed New Zealand side beset by illness as Marnus Labuschagne scores his fourth century of the summer on day one of the third Test at the SCG.

column2: 'When it gets smoky, we're coming off': Tim Paine says officials watching air quality for Sydney Test
column3: The Australian skipper backs officials to make the right call, but admits that if air quality deteriorates, it could result in a loss of play at the third Test against New Zealand, starting at the SCG tomorrow.

column2: Australian players back five days as the 'ultimate' Test as ICC considers radical change
column3: Opinion is divided about whether men's Test matches should be reduced from five days to four, but the Australian players don't want to see any change to the traditional format.

column2: Australian cricket team's year of growth and change ends on a high
column3: Australia's men's Test team has put the unpleasantness of 2018 largely behind it, and leaves 2019 in solid shape with a lot to look forward to, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Teams happy after Big Bash umpire with 'itchy nose' overrules himself
column3: Players and officials laugh off one of the more bizarre umpiring incidents in Big Bash League history, when Greg Davidson changes his mind midway through an LBW decision.

column2: Umpire causes uproar when LBW call turns to a nose scratch (Fox Cricket)
column3: Adelaide Strikers' Rashid Khan thought he had trapped Renegades batsman Beau Webster in front but umpire Greg Davidson changed his mind on an LBW decision halfway through raising his finger to signal a wicket.

column2: James Pattinson creates hometown joy as Siddle departs
column3: For years James Pattinson has been a presence in Australian cricket through his absence, but on a day when fellow Victorian Peter Siddle departed for good, the imposing pace bowler made his physical presence felt at the MCG, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Peter Siddle announces retirement from international cricket
column3: Peter Siddle calls time on his international cricket career, ending more than 11 years of donning the Baggy Green for Australia.

column2: Australia clinches series victory with big win over New Zealand at the MCG
column3: Tom Blundell fought gamely with a terrific century, but it was not enough to prevent a hefty 247-run loss to Australia, who sealed a trans-Tasman trophy victory with a day to spare.

column2: Cummins's brilliance brutally exposes New Zealand's failings
column3: Pat Cummins' five-wicket haul puts Australia into an insurmountable position at the MCG, continuing New Zealand's failings with the bat amid another DRS controversy.

column2: Cummins masterclass sets Australia up for big win at MCG
column3: Australia is primed for a big, series-clinching win in the second Test against New Zealand after skittling the tourists for just 148 at the MCG.

column2: Cricket hardly matters on a Melbourne day close enough to perfect
column3: Australia makes the most of almost-perfect weather at the MCG on the second day of the Boxing Day Test — the kind of Melbourne day you only get a handful of in any given year.

column2: New Zealand reeling at stumps after Travis Head century at MCG
column3: Travis Head falls for 114 after claiming his second Test century as Australia is dismissed for 467 on day two of the second Test at the MCG, leaving New Zealand a mammoth task.

column2: Steve Smith has helped Australia gain the edge over New Zealand ahead of day two of Boxing Day Test at the MCG
column3: After a slow start to the day, Steve Smith's unbeaten 77 led Australia to 4 for 257 at stumps.

column2: Cricket Australia told to raise its voice on climate change amid claim extreme heat is threatening Boxing Day Test
column3: A report commissioned by conservationists warns that under current climate models it could become too dangerous to play the Test in December, suggesting the event may be moved to relatively cooler months such as November or March.

column2: New Zealand made to rue missed opportunities on Boxing Day
column3: The Black Caps have had to wait 32 years to play a Test match at the MCG, but after a brilliant start, a resilient Steve Smith innings has left the tourists pondering what might have been.

column2: Smith resists New Zealand at the MCG as Australia takes day one honours
column3: Australia recovers from a difficult start as Steve Smith shows his resilience against New Zealand's bumper barrage in the Boxing Day Test at the MCG.

column2: In-form Warner cleared to play in Boxing Day Test after injury scare
column3: Australia coach Justin Langer says David Warner will be a certain starter against New Zealand on Boxing Day, after the in-form opener completed training with a strapped thumb.

column2: Siddle treated for smoke inhalation, but Cricket Australia says it has a plan for SCG haze
column3: Australian Test bowler Peter Siddle was treated for smoke inhalation following the abandoned Big Bash match in Canberra, as Cricket Australia anticipates treating smoke-enforced interruptions like rain delays at the SCG Test.

column2: US baseball star quits Australian team as bushfire smoke wreaks havoc on sporting events
column3: Heavy pollution across the south-east of the country is forcing sport administrators to rethink match schedules, and a star US baseballer has left Australia over concerns about the health effects of bushfire smoke.

column2: Curator will continue to push boundaries with MCG pitch
column3: Despite seeing a recent Sheffield Shield game abandoned over a dangerous pitch, the MCG staff still hope to provide an "exciting" pitch on Boxing Day.

column2: Brisbane heat batsman Chris Lynn fell just short of the big bash league's fastest-ever century last night
column3: Brisbane heat batsman Chris Lynn fell just short of the big bash league's fastest-ever century last night.

column2: What does the BBL cancellation say about cricket in a changing climate?
column3: Not being able to watch cricket isn't a tragedy and wouldn't make anyone's list of the worst things about bushfire season, but how players can cope in rising temperatures is one more thing to think about in a changing climate, writes Richard Hinds.

column2: Chris Lynn falls a few metres short of fastest Big Bash century
column3: An explosive session of Lynnsanity ends six runs short of another BBL century as the Brisbane Heat star puts the Sydney Sixers to the sword.

column2: BBL match cancelled due to hazardous bushfire smoke
column3: A Big Bash League match in Canberra between the Sydney Thunder and Adelaide Strikers has been cancelled with hazardous levels of bushfire smoke making playing conditions unsafe.

column2: Thunder frustrated as BBL match abandoned due to thick bushfire smoke haze
column3: Bushfire smoke shrouds Manuka Oval in Canberra, forcing the abandonment of a Big Bash League game between the Thunder and Strikers

column2: Concrete slab under drop-in pitch identified as the problem with the MCG pitch
column3: The MCG pitch has provided several years of dull draws and even an abandoned match due to safety concerns, but curators say removing the concrete slab underneath the pitch will rectify the problems.

column2: Pat Cummins's extraordinary windfall
column3: Australian fast bowler Pat Cummins smashes the record for the biggest cheque handed out to an overseas player in the IPL auction, being acquired by the Kolkata Knight Riders for $3.17 million.

column2: No chance of DRS in this BBL season, but time-outs here to stay
column3: Despite a contentious start to the new season, and the divisive new tactical time-out system, Cricket Australia says there is no chance of introducing DRS for this Big Bash season.

column2: New look, new era for the Perth Scorchers, but returning to the Big Bash penthouse is easier said than done
column3: The Perth Scorchers have been one of the most successful domestic Twenty20 teams in world cricket, but after finishing bottom in the BBL last season, the pressure is on for the three-time champions to return to the finals.

column2: Best in the world: Ellyse Perry named ICC women's player of the year
column3: After another stellar calendar year for Australia, superstar all-rounder Ellyse Perry wins the Rachael Heyhoe-Flint award for ICC women's cricketer of the year.

column2: Razed by fire in February, gold rush town celebrates return of cricket to its historic ground
column3: Surviving on a mountain top for over a century, Walhalla's historic cricket ground was destroyed by fire in February. A new synthetic wicket has allowed it to host its first match since then.

column2: Siddle recalled to Test squad, post-World Cup ODI team given a shake up
column3: Australia brings veteran quick Peter Siddle into its squad for the Boxing Day Test against New Zealand in place of the injured Josh Hazlewood, while some big names are left out of the latest ODI squad.

column2: Controversial English cricket star Alex Hales walks road to redemption in BBL
column3: After being kicked off England's Cricket World Cup squad, Alex Hales is looking for redemption in the Big Bash with Sydney Thunder.

column2: Nathan Lyon the quiet key to Australia's undermanned Test win
column3: Modesty has long defined Nathan Lyon's career, but by the end of the Perth Test he was showing a bit of his own kind of swagger. He deserved every bit of it, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Paceman Mitchell Starc has led Australia to a commanding victory in the First Test against New Zealand
column3: Starc took 4-45 as the Black Caps were bowled out for 171, some 296 runs shy of the Aussies target.

column2: Australia wins first Test in Perth after NZ's resistance finally crumbles
column3: The winning margin is a massive 296 runs in the end but New Zealand's batsmen make Australia's bowlers work hard to close out the first Test in Perth.

column2: Peter Siddle in line for shock Boxing Day recall
column3: Australia coach Justin Langer reveals that Peter Siddle could be in line to replace injured quick Josh Hazlewood for the Boxing Day Test.

column2: Mitchell Starc will never be a model of consistency, but right now he is running hot
column3: Mitchell Starc's five wickets in the first innings of the day-night Test against New Zealand in Perth shows that in the right conditions, there is nobody better, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Black Caps do well to engineer late collapse, but Australia still in winning position
column3: Despite a late batting collapse under the lights, Australia ends day three of the first Test with a potentially match-winning lead in Perth.

column2: Australia dominates New Zealand at Perth Stadium
column3: Australia is in a dominant position against New Zealand after the second day's play in the first Test in Perth thanks to some gritty batting and a feisty late spell with the ball.

column2: If you don't get why people like cricket, last night in Perth is a good place to start
column3: For fans of Test cricket, explaining why we like cricket is not always easy, but the first half-hour under lights as Australia were running rampant against New Zealand's world-class batsmen is about as good as it gets, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Starc blasts through New Zealand top order after Australia posts strong total
column3: After Australia posts 416 all out thanks to some gritty lower order batting before Mitchell Starc takes four wickets to put the hosts well in control in Perth.

column2: Steve Smith looked decidedly human against New Zealand, and the Black Caps deserve the credit
column3: When coming up against a team with a transcendent batter, every team zeroes in on that superstar. For New Zealand in Perth, it paid off with the big scalp of Steve Smith, who looked like a completely different player than the man who slayed England, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Kiwis keep it tight but Labuschagne puts Australia in front on day one
column3: Despite some miserly New Zealand bowling, Marnus Labuschagne's terrific form continues as he scores his third straight century in the day-night Test in Perth.

column2: Four days in a row of 40 degrees triggers rare deadly heatwave warning for Perth
column3: Four consecutive days of 40C heat are expected from Thursday during the Perth Test between Australia and New Zealand.

column2: He's one of the world's best batsmen, and NZ's Kane Williamson knows he's a target in Perth
column3: Kiwi batsman Kane Williamson is a superstar of world cricket, and he looms as the major obstacle standing between Australia and Test victory.

column2: Former Test star calls for action after playing out Shield clash in 'toxic' Sydney smoke haze
column3: New South Wales and Queensland players struggle at a Sydney Cricket Ground blanketed by smoke haze from nearby bushfires, with Test spinner Steve O'Keefe saying the conditions are "toxic" and "shocking".

column2: MCG curators to walk balance beam between boredom and bedlam with Boxing Day Test pitch
column3: Two years ago, the MCG pitch was officially condemned for being too boring. This week, a Sheffield Shield game at the ground was called off because the deck was too dangerous. Now, organisers have to find a happy medium before the Boxing Day Test.

column2: First Test set for a scorcher as potential heatwave conditions to hit Perth this week
column3: Perth is looking at potential heatwave conditions for the first time since 2016, with temperatures expected to hover close to 40 degrees Celsius from Wednesday to Sunday this week.

column2: 'You get told about Bradman but not our mob': Test medal to honour Indigenous cricketing icon
column3: A new medal will be awarded to the best player of the Boxing Day Test from next year, remembering the largely untold story of the first Australian cricket team to tour England.

column2: Forget the MCG pitch, Australia's openers are more concerned about Perth
column3: David Warner and Joe Burns back the MCG curator to sort out its pitch issues before the Boxing Day Test — but searing heat in Perth could make this week's Test wicket just as fraught.

column2: Brisbane Heat defend WBBL title with six-wicket win over Adelaide Strikers
column3: Playing in front of a sold-out home crowd in Brisbane, the Heat show why they are the dominant force in women's domestic T20 cricket with victory over the Strikers in the final.

column2: Shield match abandoned due to MCG pitch problems
column3: Officials apologise for the state of the MCG pitch, which causes the abandonment of a Sheffield Shield game, but they express confidence things will improve for the Boxing Day Test in 18 days.

column2: Adelaide Strikers to face Brisbane Heat in WBBL final
column3: Sophie Devine provides the fireworks to help Adelaide Strikers into the WBBL final where they will face defending champions Brisbane Heat.

column2: Sheffield Shield match suspended due to unsafe MCG pitch
column3: A Sheffield Shield match between WA and Victoria at the MCG has been suspended due to an unsafe pitch. A number of players were hit by unpredictable bounce before the captains came together to cancel the match.

column2: Dangerous MCG pitch forces suspension of Sheffield Shield match
column3: The MCG pitch is deemed unsafe in a Sheffield Shield match in what may prove to be a significant embarrassment for Cricket Australia in the build-up to its marquee Boxing Day Test in Melbourne.

column2: Australia's women cricketers love T20 and WBBL, but they want to play more Tests
column3: This year's WBBL has again shown the massive interest in T20 cricket, but if you ask the players, they want more women's Test matches in the future.

column2: Shamsi dismissed Wihab Lubbe before celebrating by turning a red handkerchief from his pocket into a stick
column3: The incident happened between the match between Paarl Rocks and Durban Heat in South Africa's premier T20 tournament.

column2: 'Look at that! It's magic': Trick lights up South African T20 match
column3: A South African spin bowler lifts his wicket celebration straight out of Hogwarts, magically turning a handkerchief into a metal rod.

column2: Who produced the sporting moment of 2019?
column3: Ash Barty's French Open triumph and rise to the top of women's tennis was a huge story in 2019, as was Tiger Woods once again winning a major at Augusta National, but the most significant moment came from a man who simply took a stand.

column2: Former England captain and Ashes hero Bob Willis dies aged 70
column3: Willis — who will be remembered for his long, curving run-up and inspired spells of fast bowling — played in 90 tests and 64 one-day internationals from 1971 to 1984.

column2: Steve Smith denies claims he is 'white-anting' Test captain Tim Paine
column3: The star batsman says he was offering suggestions and was not trying to undermine his captain after being accused by Test great Ian Chappell of moving fielders around against Pakistan.

column2: Joe Denly's dropped catch for the ages the 'highlight' in NZ vs England draw
column3: England's Joe Denly hits the headlines for all the wrong reasons, as his unfathomable dropped catch gives NZ skipper Kane Williamson a life on the way to a century on day five in Hamilton.

column2: England's Joe Denly drops sitter in Test against Black Caps
column3: England's Joe Denly drops an easy catch hit straight to him by New Zealand batter Kane Williamson.

column2: At just 20, Cameron Green could be the most perfect cricketer Australia has produced
column3: If you were building a prototype for the perfect cricketer, it would be hard to go past emerging Australian all-rounder Cameron Green — but his early promise has led to great expectations.

column2: Australia complete clean sweep after Lyon's five-wicket haul secured an innings and 48-run win
column3: The balance of the side suddenly appears a strength of Australia, after a long period of selection uncertainty.

column2: Australia sweeps series in Adelaide on the back of Lyon's five-wicket haul
column3: Nathan Lyon takes five wickets on day four as Australia beats Pakistan by an innings and 48 runs in Adelaide to complete a 2-0 series sweep.

column2: Are people dismissing David Warner's brilliance simply because they don't like him?
column3: David Warner is undeniably better at home than he is away, but Richard Hinds reckons the criticism he attracts is far from objective analysis of his ability.

column2: Australia still in the box seat despite frustrating third day against Pakistan
column3: Victory is well within Australia's sights despite Pakistan's impressive batting and its own general sloppiness on the third day in Adelaide, with the tourists still 248 runs away from making the hosts bat again.

column2: David Warner's triple ton answers the critics — even if their hits keep coming
column3: David Warner may not be a batsman who can travel the world, dominating Tests in all conditions. His sublime triple century in Adelaide shows that doesn't have to matter, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Record kings, passing Bradman and going berserk: The Test triple tons that live long in the memory
column3: David Warner's career-best triple century puts him in rarefied air in the annals of Test cricket. After notching only the 31st triple ton ever scored in Test cricket, it puts the Aussie opener alongside some of the game's true greats.

column2: Australia and David Warner bats Pakistan into submission before Starc strikes with the ball
column3: Australia rips through Pakistan's batting line up after David Warner's sensational 335 puts Australia onto a dominant position on day two of the second Test at Adelaide Oval.

column2: Pakistan do teenagers no favours with baptisms of fire
column3: There's little obvious benefit for the touring side's young bowlers experiencing one bad match and then potentially not playing for months or even years, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Chewie on your bails: Regional cricket league stumped by sticky wickets
column3: A country Victorian cricket competition investigates after chewing gum was found stuck underneath the bails in a division one match.

column2: Warner, Labuschagne punish Pakistan in dominant display under lights
column3: David Warner and Marnus Labuschagne centuries help Australia to dominant position over Pakistan on day one of the second day-night Test at Adelaide Oval.

column2: Aussie cricket great Alex Blackwell 'satisfied' to call time on 18-year career
column3: Legendary Australian cricketer Alex Blackwell will retire at the end of the WBBL season, bringing an end to a decorated career that has lasted almost two decades.

column2: 'No boundaries' for cricketers living with disabilities, Nathan Lyon says
column3: The passion brought to the field by cricketers living with disabilities is proof that cricket is Australia's number one sport, off-spin legend Nathan Lyon has said.

column2: Delissa Kimmince fell out of love with cricket, but one thing brought her back
column3: Delissa Kimmince, once one of Australian cricket's brightest young stars, was burnt out and over the game. She left the country and the sport she "hated", but her time away has helped her find a way back.

column2: Former Test batsman George Bailey to become national selector following upcoming retirement
column3: George Bailey will draw the curtain on a decorated career that includes helping Australia win an Ashes series 5-0 to become a national selector early next year.

column2: Shaun Marsh's stoic century seals Western Australia's domestic one-day cup victory
column3: Shaun Marsh may be out of favour with national selectors but he provides a timely reminder of his batting talent, as he guides Western Australia to a triumph over Queensland in the domestic one-day cup final.

column2: NZ Cricket to apologise to England's Jofra Archer for 'unacceptable' racist abuse
column3: England's Test loss to New Zealand in Mount Manganui is further soured after the paceman is racially abused by a fan as he walks off the ground.

column2: Please ignore the death notices, Test cricket is alive and kicking
column3: A small crowd in attendance at Gabba for Australia's opening Test against Pakistan reignites suggestions the five-day game is dying, but any such fears are unfounded, writes Richard Hinds.

column2: Australia crushed Pakistan by an innings and five runs in the first Test in Brisbane
column3: The second and final Test begins at Adelaide Oval on Thursday.

column2: Pakistan star Babar Azam makes Brisbane breakthrough against Aussie attack
column3: Pakistan batsman Babar Azam's century in Brisbane doesn't prove he can play Test cricket — he's just shown his mettle under Australian conditions, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Australia eventually clinches victory in first Test against Pakistan
column3: It may have taken a little longer than it would have hoped, but Australia claims a big victory over Pakistan in the first Test at the Gabba, running out a winner by an innings and five runs late on the fourth day.

column2: Labuschagne shows ruthless streak at number three in dominant Gabba display
column3: Last summer, Marnus Labuschagne resembled a bits-and-pieces Test player — but his ruthless day three display for Australia shows he is growing into a dominant one, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Aussies storming towards victory after Labuschagne bats Pakistan into submission
column3: Pakistan has a mountain to climb to avoid an innings defeat in the first Test, after a day three dominated by Marnus Labuschagne's batting brilliance and a late burst by the Aussie bowlers.

column2: For a player with plenty of critics, the timing of Mitch Marsh's snap was 'horrific'
column3: When Mitch Marsh punched a dressing room wall at the WACA Ground, derailing his Test cricket career, it was a brain snap borne out of a building mass of tension.

column2: Warner's partnership with Burns in first Test shows what's old is new again
column3: The decision to go back to the well by selecting David Warner and Joe Burns to open the batting against Pakistan pays off, suggesting Australia has at last found the right partnership at the top of the order, writes Geoff Lemon.

column2: Warner fires with unbeaten century as Australia dominate Pakistan
column3: David Warner hits an unbeaten 151 against Pakistan in his first Test on home soil after a 12-month ban. With a lead of 72 on the second day, Australia is in a dominant position against Pakistan.

column2: Australia crushes Pakistan on day two with Warner and Burns leading from the front
column3: Australia's latest opening partnership of David Warner and Joe Burns piles on 222 runs, battering Pakistan into submission as Australia builds a 72-run lead on day two of the first Test at the Gabba.

column2: Australia's bowlers find a way to turn the tide at the Gabba
column3: The blistering heat at the Gabba provided far-from-ideal conditions for Australia's attack, but the manner in which Pakistan were dismissed for 240 after they chose to bat on the first day bodes well for the home team's summer ahead.

column2: Pakistan was aiming for first test win in Australia since 1995
column3: Pakistan aiming for first test win in Australia since 1995

column2: Jess Jonassen reflects on her setbacks and how it has grounded her in life and on the cricket field
column3: The Australian all-rounder opens up about how her knee injury had took a mental toll on her during Austraila's 50-over World Cup campaign.

column2: After missing out on the last T20 World Cup, the WBBL's leading wicket-taker is primed for 2020
column3: Queensland all-rounder Jess Jonassen travelled to the World Cup in 2018, but did not get a game due to injury. This time around, she is hell-bent on making her mark.

column2: Australia takes day-one honours after late Starc blast at Gabba
column3: Mitchell Starc's expert use of the second new ball late on day one leaves Pakistan chasing the game in the first Test, all out for 240 at the Gabba after a promising start.

column2: How science is cracking the code behind Steve Smith's batting success
column3: Part way through an innings, Steve Smith made the incredible decision to change the way he would bat. It was a decision that altered the course of his career.

column2: Joe Burns to partner David Warner as part of Australia's 'odd couple' for first Test
column3: Joe Burns will partner David Warner at the top of Australia's batting order for the first time in three years in the opening Test against Pakistan, as Mitchell Starc makes a return to the home side's pace attack.

column2: Her ban may be heavy-handed, but Emily Smith broke Cricket Australia's golden rule
column3: When compared to other sporting sins WBBL player Emily Smith's decision to poke fun at her place the batting line-up may seem innocent, but it goes to the heart of Cricket Australia's biggest fears, writes Chris Rowbottom.

column2: How the only girl on the boys' team became the Australian cricket captain
column3: Meg Lanning didn't have any female cricket player role models growing up, but now millions of young girls look up to her.

column2: Steve Smith the batsman better for Australia, Border says
column3: Some people think it's a matter of time — and the end of his leadership ban next March — before Steve Smith regains the Australian captaincy. But Allan Border isn't sure it's a good idea.

column2: Australian cricket has rediscovered the line
column3: Cape Town showed how quickly reputational damage could be self-inflicted, so in light of recent incidents, Australian cricket needs to remind itself of where the line is.

column2: WBBL player's Instagram post of team line-up sees her banned under anti-corruption code
column3: Cricket Australia comes down hard on Hobart Hurricanes WBBL player Emily Smith for a breach of its anti-corruption code, handing out a 12-month suspension after she posted a team list on social media.

column2: Ellyse Perry sidelined in WBBL but cleared of serious shoulder injury
column3: Ellyse Perry's shoulder injury is not as serious as first thought, allaying fears the outstanding all-rounder may have been in doubt for Australia's Women's T20 World Cup campaign on home soil next year.

column2: Ellyse Perry injured as Sixers lose on last-ball six against Renegades
column3: The Melbourne Renegades' Courtney Webb bombs a six off the final ball of the team's run chase to beat the Sydney Sixers, in a loss that was made more painful by Ellyse Perry's shoulder injury.

column2: James Pattinson to miss first Test after code of conduct breach
column3: James Pattinson will not contest a charge from Cricket Australia that he used abusive language during a Sheffield Shield match and will serve a one-match suspension.

column2: From street cricket to handcrafted bats: How one man's love for the game led to a business
column3: For Shashi Samprathi, growing up in India meant he was "cricket mad" from an early age. But in order for him to play the sport he loved, he had to improvise.

column2: David Warner 'wouldn't shut up' during Headingley Test, Ben Stokes says in new book
column3: Ben Stokes's match-winning innings in the Headingley Ashes Test — named by some as the greatest knock of all time — can be credited to David Warner's refusal to stop "chirping", according to the England star.

column2: Are the mental health challenges young athletes face too great?
column3: In a week where a Test aspirant rules himself out of selection because of mental health concerns and a teenager is hailed as Australian cricket's "next big thing", the pressure placed on young sportspeople is again under the spotlight, writes Richard Hinds.

column2: Bancroft earns shock Australia recall, Khawaja and Siddle dropped
column3: Australia names its Test squad to take on Pakistan at the Gabba and in Adelaide, with Cameron Bancroft a notable inclusion.

column2: Young gun Will Pucovski rules himself out of Test contention over mental health concerns
column3: Young Victorian batsman Will Pucovski, tipped as possible inclusion in Australia's Test squad, removes himself from consideration to deal with his mental health.

column2: A young 'Dennis Lillee?' Teen paceman Naseem Shah gets Pakistan excited

column2: Women's sport is booming, but so too is the rate of serious knee injuries

The Socceroos' opener against France clashes with the Wallabies, AFL, NRL and one-day international cricket tomorrow but if you aren't watching the action from Russia, you are not watching the big game, writes Richard Hinds.

column2: Port Adelaide's new logo comes under fire from designer claiming the club ripped off his design

column2: Andrew Fagan comments on management dismissals

column2: Adelaide Crows to axe football chief and assistant coach following external review
column3: The mass exodus at the Adelaide Crows is continuing, with the club announcing it will axe football chief Brett Burton and assistant coach Scott Camporeale following the completion of its external review, chaired by Hawthorn legend Jason Dunstall.

column2: Everyone (and their dog) seems to want a Tasmanian AFL team — will it convince the executive?

column2: Tim Kelly reveals the family struggle behind his blockbuster trade to the West Coast Eagles
column3: Star midfielder Tim Kelly says having two of his three sons diagnosed with autism while living on the other side of the country from his family was a major factor pushing his trade from Geelong to the West Coast Eagles.

column2: Football club embroiled in sexual harassment controversy apologises, but remains in limbo
column3: An Adelaide council insists it has made a suburban football club facing eviction fully aware of the sexual harassment allegations against some of its players, despite claims by the club it remains in the dark. Meanwhile, another club facing financial woes has been given a reprieve.

column2: Geelong's Tim Kelly could be headed for West Coast — but is there room for him?
column3: Managers from the nation's 18 AFL clubs have 10 days to land the deals they believe will propel their side to the next level as the trade period gets underway in Melbourne — and star midfielder Tim Kelly is right in the mix for the West Coast Eagles.

column2: Players accused of 'aggressive and damaging' campaign as AFLW deal dispute intensifies
column3: Divisions in the AFLW over a proposed collective bargaining agreement put the future of the league's 2020 season in limbo, as the head of the players' association criticises a "damaging" campaign against the deal.

column2: 'Widespread dissatisfaction': AFL women's league dispute over number of games played per season
column3: The future of the AFL women's league is hanging in the balance, with some players threatening to reject a deal "final offer" deal from the AFL because it does not offer enough games per season.

column2: 'This is it': Gary Ablett to retire in 2020 after extending Cats contract
column3: Geelong legend Gary Ablett ends speculation about his playing future by announcing the 2020 AFL season will be his last after re-signing with the Cats.

column2: Geelong star Tim Kelly requests AFL trade to West Coast
column3: Tim Kelly confirms what Geelong supporters have feared for some time, a trade request to join the West Coast Eagles for the 2020 AFL season.

column2: Alleged Adelaide Oval brawlers involved in altercation outside court
column3: Two people charged with aggravated assault over a fight at an AFL game at Adelaide Oval are engaged in another altercation outside court.

column2: Fremantle's decision to put Justin Longmuir in charge makes sense — now for the hard part

column2: Gold Coast Suns to receive priority draft picks
column3: The struggling Suns will be given priority draft picks for the next three years, along with an expansion of academy player access.

column2: AFL bosses throw draft-pick lifeline to floundering Gold Coast Suns
column3: An assistance package which includes the first two picks in the 2019 player draft will be handed to the struggling Gold Coast Suns to help the club "deliver upon their football strategy".

column2: 'It means everything to me': Longmuir returns to Fremantle Dockers as coach
column3: Fremantle appoints former player and current Collingwood assistant coach Justin Longmuir as head coach after sacking Ross Lyon last month, with Longmuir declaring he has "unfinished business" at the Dockers.

column2: Richmond celebrate their grand final win
column3: AFL grand final winners Richmond celebrate with the Tiger army at Punt Road Oval.

column2: Richmond CEO Brendon Gale on 'special' grand final win

column2: Richmond faithful celebrate 'surreal' AFL grand final win with premiership players
column3: The premiership party for Richmond continues as thousands of fans gather at Punt Road oval to celebrate the Tigers' grand final victory over Greater Western Sydney.

column2: Toby Greene's father faces Melbourne court over alleged police assault at MCG

column2: The man who made footy's most special story possible says his sacrifice was an 'easy decision'
