column3: Carlos Ghosn's daring escape to Lebanon confounds and embarrasses authorities, with neighbours of the former Nissan chairman joking the mysterious circumstances surrounding his escape from Japan could be the subject of a future streaming television series.

column2: Detroit firefighters investigated over NYE selfie in front of burning house
column3: Detroit's Fire Commissioner blasts a group of firefighters who were photographed posing in front of a home engulfed in flames, labelling the stunt "inappropriate and unprofessional".

column2: Julian Castro leaves Democrats' 2020 race as more famous front-runners remain
column3: Julian Castro, the grandson of a Mexican immigrant who became San Antonio mayor and the only Latino still making a 2020 Democratic presidential run, withdraws to leave 14 candidates seeking the party's nomination to take on Republican President Donald Trump in November.

column2: 'I realised that I was deceived': Meet the North Korean defectors desperate to get home
column3: It's a rare thing for a South Korean to defect to the North. But on the Korean peninsula, where the two countries are still at war, any defections are deeply politicised and fodder for propaganda.

column2: In 30 years, there will be nearly 10 billion people on Earth. Here's how we feed them
column3: In a world with a growing population and diminishing resources, the farmer of the future could be a scientist in a lab coat. They've already designed vegan 'eggs,' fruit fly larvae protein and a zero-kilojoule sweetener which builds muscle.

column2: Taiwan's highest-ranking general among eight dead in helicopter crash
column3: Taiwan's top military official dies alongside seven others after a helicopter carrying them to visit soldiers crashed in a mountainous area near the capital Taipei.

column2: 2019 one of the safest years for air travel, despite the Ethiopian Airlines crash
column3: A Dutch aviation safety organisation says last year was the seventh-safest year on record for commercial flying, even though Boeing's 737 MAX 8 jets were grounded following a disaster that killed 157 people.

column2: 'The water kept rising': Jakarta residents inundated by flooding that killed 30
column3: Just after lunch on New Year's Day, Nidya Desianti received a text alert, telling her to evacuate from her Jakarta home. But it was too late to leave.

column2: A humiliating roast by Joe Biden may have turned Rudy Giuliani into Trump's avenger
column3: In 2006, Rudy Giuliani was the most popular politician in America. Today, he's loathed by Republicans, blamed by Democrats and stuck at the heart of Donald Trump's impeachment scandal.

column2: Israeli PM seeks immunity from prosecution on corruption charges
column3: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says he will seek parliamentary immunity from prosecution on corruption charges, likely delaying any trial until after elections in March.

column2: NBA legend Michael Jordan pays tribute to man who 'allowed me to succeed'
column3: David Stern, the basketball-loving lawyer and administrator who helped turn the US basketball league into one of the biggest sporting brands in the world through the boom years of the 1980s, '90s and noughties, dies aged 77 from a brain haemorrhage.

column2: Sky lanterns likely cause of German zoo fire that killed 30 animals
column3: A fire races through a zoo in western Germany in the first few minutes of the new year, killing more than 30 animals, including apes, orangutans, monkeys, bats and birds.

column2: 'We are basically living naked': The complicated truth about China's Social Credit System
column3: Beijing is amassing a colossal amount of individual and company data as part of its ambitious plans to build a national Social Credit System pegged to be fully operational by 2020. So what can we expect this year?

column2: Iraqi protesters withdraw from Baghdad US embassy after violent protests
column3: Supporters of Iran-backed Iraqi paramilitary groups who stormed the US embassy's perimeter in two days of protests withdraw after the US threatens reprisals against Iran.

column2: Pacific nation of Palau bans sunscreen toxic to coral reefs in environmental world first
column3: The Pacific nation of Palau is the first country in the world to ban sunscreen which contains chemicals that are "incredibly toxic" to its coral reefs.

column2: Floods in Indonesia's capital kill 21 people and force thousands to evacuate
column3: At least 21 people have been killed and thousands of people evacuated as flash flooding submerges parts of the Indonesia's capital and nearby towns.

column2: Tear gas, water cannons and smashed ATMs mark Hong Kong new year protests
column3: A march drawing tens of thousands of anti-government protesters in Hong Kong on New Year's Day becomes chaotic as police fire several rounds of tear gas and water cannon at crowds including families before halting the event.

column2: Disgruntled Pope Francis apologises for slapping woman's arm to free himself from her grasp
column3: Pope Francis apologises for losing his patience and setting a "bad example" after he slapped a woman's arm when she grabbed hold of his hand and yanked him towards her.

column2: North Korea's Kim Jong-un threatens 'shocking action' against US
column3: The standstill between the US and North Korea over denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula continues, with Kim Jong-un accusing the Trump administration of dragging its feet and warning his country will soon show a new strategic weapon to the world.

column2: 'This is not a warning, it is a threat': Trump's escalation of tensions with Iran may be a preview of 2020
column3: As the US and Iran continue to battle for influence in Iraq, an attack on the US embassy in Baghdad sends a clear message to the White House, writes Kathryn Diss.

column2: Hong Kong rings in 2020 with democracy chants instead of harbour fireworks
column3: Thousands of Hong Kong revellers welcome 2020 on the picturesque Victoria Harbour, breaking into pro-democracy chants as the clocks strike midnight.

column2: Thailand has a big plastic problem and 12-year-old Lilly is helping to fix it
column3: Thailand is banning single-use plastic bags and 12-year-old Lilly is a big reason why. But it hasn't been easy to get people to take her seriously.

column2: Nissan ex-head Carlos Ghosn flees to Lebanon, says he won't be 'held hostage' by Japan
column3: Ousted Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn is in his childhood home of Lebanon after fleeing what he said was a "rigged" justice system in Japan, raising questions about how he got away while on bail.

column2: Iraqi protesters break in to US embassy in Baghdad angered over US air strikes
column3: Dozens of militia fighters enraged by American air strikes on Iraq broke in to the US Embassy in Baghdad, as demonstrations outside the compound turned violent.

column2: Huawei says 'survival' is its priority in 2020, after US blacklisting
column3: Chinese telecoms giant Huawei says "survival" will be its priority in 2020 after announcing lower than expected annual sales revenue, largely as the result of a US trade blacklisting.

column2: Trade deal between US and China could be signed next week
column3: A White House trade adviser says the 86-page agreement is being translated and double checked ahead of the Chinese Vice-Premier's visit to Washington.

column2: Hundreds celebrate after Sudan sentences 29 security agents to death over protester killing
column3: A Sudanese court sentences 29 members of the country's national intelligence to death by hanging for torturing and killing a detained protester during the uprising against longtime autocrat Omar al-Bashir.

column2: Americans actually want tougher gun laws, but there's a major reason they won't see them
column3: In 2019, there has been more than one mass shooting per day in the United States. But the nation's resistance to gun control is about more than just the frontier spirit of the American people — and it's unlikely to change anytime soon, writes Shaun Ratcliff and Zoe Meers.

column2: Top Iraq militia chief warns of 'very tough' response to US air strikes
column3: A top Iraqi militia leader warns of a strong response against US forces in Iraq following air strikes that hit several bases of his Iranian-backed group, killing at least 25 people.

column2: Greta Thunberg and David Attenborough unite to call for climate change action
column3: Two titan climate campaigners, Greta Thunberg and Sir David Attenborough, join forces to push politicians and businesses to step up action on climate change after a year in which schoolchildren took to the world's streets in protest.

column2: Woman lied about being gang raped by Israeli teens, court finds
column3: A court in Cyprus finds a 19-year-old British woman guilty of fabricating claims she was gang-raped by 12 Israeli teenagers six months ago.

column2: Chinese scientist who 'gene-edited' babies jailed for three years
column3: Chinese scientist He Jiankui, who claims he made the world's first "gene-edited" babies by altering human embryos in 2018, is convicted on charges of practising medicine illegally, according to Chinese state media.

column2: The Mandalorian's finale twist is a bigger deal than it seems
column3: The flagship Star Wars series has wrapped up its first season, and its finale packed a big surprise (that wasn't Baby Yoda). Here's what we know about it.

column2: China ends forced labour for sex workers
column3: China will no longer punish sex workers with forced labour in "custody and education" centres, where detainees were made to make toys and other items.

column2: Death toll rises to 90 in Mogadishu blast as Turkey evacuates wounded
column3: A Turkish military cargo plane lands in the Somali capital to evacuate people badly wounded in a devastating truck bombing that killed at least 90 people including two Turkish nationals.

column2: Texan churchgoers shoot gunman dead in livestreamed attack
column3: Two parishioners kill a man seconds after he pulls out his gun in a US church near Fort Worth, Texas, in an incident that leaves another man dead and another in a critical condition.

column2: US strikes in Iraq and Syria target Iranian-backed Shiite militia group
column3: US warplanes bomb Iranian-backed militia fighters in Iraq and Syria, after a US civilian contractor dies in a rocket attack on an Iraqi military base.

column2: Anti-Semitic attacks mar Hanukkah celebrations in New York and London
column3: Hanukkah celebrations on both sides of the Atlantic have been marred by anti-Semitic attacks, one on a rabbi's home in New York and another at a London synagogue and surrounding shops.

column2: Big Ben to ring in new year with a new look after facelift
column3: Big Ben, situated within London's Palace of Westminster, will ring in the United Kingdom's new year with a blue face, after extensive works to restore the iconic landmark.

column2: Samoa lifts six-week state of emergency after bringing measles outbreak under control
column3: The Samoa Government ends aggressive measures, including closing schools and restricting travel, after a vaccination program helps contain the outbreak of the virus which killed 81 people and infected more than 5,600.

column2: 'Age of mass shootings': US mass killings hit new high in 2019
column3: The United States has hit a new high in 2019 but it's an unwanted one with more mass killings taking place than in any other year since the 1970s, and more than 80 per cent of them came as the result of shootings.

column2: Woman and two girls killed in avalanche
column3: Rescue workers say there was nothing the skiers cold have done to escape the 150-metre avalanche as it hurtled towards them on the slopes of the Italian Alps.

column2: Boat with human remains washes up in Japan
column3: The remains of up to seven people are found on a boat, believed to be from North Korea, that turned up on the coast of Japan.

column2: UK Government says sorry after accidentally posting Elton John's address online
column3: The first version of the New Year honours list contained the home or work addresses of more than 1,000 recipients, including singer Sir Elton John, and was visible for around an hour, according to the BBC.

column2: Hijab-wearing metalheads, kick flips and blasphemy: Inside Iran's American subculture 'problem'
column3: When you think of skateboarding and rock music, Iran isn't the country that springs to mind, but thousands of Iranians have been adopting Western subcultures for decades.
